Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Spatial Analysis of the Determinants of Setback Distance Variation Between Shale Gas Wells and Residences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate the spatial variability of municipal setback policies in major shale gas areas in Texas. In this case setback distance can be conceptualized as an absolute space between gas wells and homes, as well as the product of negotiations and knowledge transfers among key policy actors. By examining the processes underlying the way in which setback distances are set, this research will fill a knowledge gap in the understanding of the placement of shale gas wells, contribute to emergent geographical theories on the mobility of policies across institutional landscapes, and provide critical information for analyzing present and future debates surrounding shale gas drilling in populated areas. The study will use a mix of qualitative and quantitative methods and will collect data in several municipalities. First, a geographic Information System (GIS) database will be developed to identify and stratify cities based on setback distances and gas well density. Second, interviews will be conducted with multiple policy stakeholders to determine their ideas about, understanding of, and role in establishing setback policies. Interview data will be analyzed to determine how setback ordinances diffuse, mutate, and/or evolve among municipalities.

This project will contribute to on-going policy discussions about shale gas drilling and its impact on residential areas throughout the United States. Undergraduate students from underrepresented groups at the University of North Texas and Texas A&M University will be recruited to participate in the research. These students will be trained through hands-on field research and data preparation, workshops, mentoring, and will be given opportunities to publicly present their research findings. In addition, the research will become a component of an undergraduate Geography of Energy course that will include a research component. A third component incorporates the GIS products generated from this study into a module for high school students. The module will allow students to determine how GIS tools can be used to understand human dimensions of hydrocarbon extraction; it will also become a tangible educational product to foster additional outreach programs at other high schools. Finally, this study will inform local, regional, national, and international policies on shale gas drilling in populated areas. A clear understanding of the motives behind gas well ordinances and the goals of setback distances and how policies formulated in one place are applied elsewhere will be relevant for communities around the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The United States is the world’s largest producer of shale gas, an unconventional form of natural gas that requires hydraulic fracturing. After 2001, record high natural gas prices combined with advances in drilling and extraction technologies and limited federal and state environmental regulations to stimulate rapid expansion of shale gas drilling in the US. Much of the early production focused on shale plays in Texas, including the Barnett, Haynesville, and Eagle Ford. The Barnett stands out as the site where contemporary hydraulic fracturing was ‘invented’ in 1981 and it was the first major shale deposit exploited; it also has the largest proven gas reserves in the U.S. and has produced the most shale gas to date. The Barnett is also noteworthy because parts of it underlie the Dallas-Fort Worth Metroplex (DFW), the fourth most populated metropolitan area in the U.S. As a result, DFW and the Barnett are home to the world’s largest and longest experiment in urban shale gas drilling.

Our NSF-funded research project investigates how municipalities in DFW and other parts of Texas create and borrow new drilling ordinances that aim to address hydraulic fracturing as well as satisfy demands of hydrocarbon firms, property owners, and residents. For example, two cities in DFW wrote and adopted the first modern-day municipal gas drilling ordinances in 2001.  By 2014, 58 municipalities in DFW had established gas drilling regulations.  As geographers, we are interested in the spatial variation among drilling policies and why different provisions, models and regulations became common in some ordinances and absent in others. To investigate variations among urban drilling policies, we focused on the setback distances that cities use to regulate the proximity between oil and gas wells and homes, schools, and public gathering facilities.

To examine municipal setback distances, we first needed to know what distances were being used and how these varied. After we gathered the setback information, we combined it with gas well point data from the Texas Railroad Commission (the state’s oil and gas regulatory agency) into a Geographic Information System platform. We then used this spatial data to compare municipalities based on setback distances and gas well density. We stratified these and selected 15 cities for more in-depth research, including interviews with local municipal staff, elected officials, and other key actors. The interviews enabled us to determine how, why, and when setback distances were chosen. We also collected demographic, income, and gas drilling revenue data from each municipality.

Although we are still analyzing our data, we have several outcomes from this research, which can be grouped into broader community and educational outcomes, and those that are more specific, scholarly outcomes. For the broader outcomes, we trained five undergraduate students from the University of North Texas and Texas A&M University in geographical science and policy analysis through hands-on field research and data preparation, workshops, mentoring, and opportunities to publicly present our research findings.  We also developed and co-lead a field trip relating to shale gas extraction as part of our ‘Geography of Energy’ and ‘Our Energy Futures’ courses taught, respectively, at Texas A&M University and University of North Texas.  Another outcome was a high school-level module on the use of GIS tools to examine human dimensions of hydrocarbon extraction, available at http://biggs.tamu.edu/module/shalegas/.  This module is also used in introductory human geography classes at Texas A&M University.
